sample.title: How North Korea Hid an IT Workforce Inside US Companies | Exclusive Preview
sample.description:
Watch the full video here:
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2025-07-24/north-korea-infiltrated-america-by-taking-remote-us-it-jobs

This is the story of Christina Chapman, a suburban TikTok creator who ran a covert ‚Äúlaptop farm‚Äù from her Arizona home. The scheme became a gateway for North Korean IT operatives who infiltrated US companies and, according to the Justice Department, funneled millions of dollars to the North Korean government.

sample.title: A Ponzi Schemer Freed by Trump Strikes Again
sample.description:
Eli Weinstein is a convicted fraudster who stole millions of dollars from investors at the height of the pandemic. He was able to do so because President Donald Trump during his first term commuted his 24-year sentence for a previous conviction. Now Weinstein is said to be planning to ask Trump for clemency again.

Within months of his release in 2021, Weinstein returned to scamming, stealing from unsuspecting victims until he was caught and convicted again, this time sentenced to 37 years in prison. While the administration contends it carefully weighs all petitions, the case points up what critics argue is a radical new system of how presidential clemency is granted, one where financial resources, connections and politics govern who goes free and who does not. 

0:00 The cost of clemency
1:37 The deal
3:04 Eli Weinstein‚Äôs second chance
4:45 Doing something good for the world
5:42 The puppet master
7:26 The brink of destruction
10:52 The story isn‚Äôt over
13:34 The purpose of clemency
15:31 The system
17:08 Out of chances?

sample.title: 'Politics Can Be Brutal': Theresa May on Power and Populism | Leaders with Francine Lacqua
sample.description:
From Brexit and the European Union to global diplomacy, former UK Prime Minister Theresa May speaks with Francine Lacqua about her time at the pinnacle of British politics and her approach to leadership in a world she says often rewards the loudest voices. 

May reflects on her "steep learning curve" when former Conservative leader David Cameron appointed her home secretary, including having to respond to a series of terrorist attacks. 

May, who started her career at the Bank of England, also discusses the future of her own party at a time when Nigel Farage's right-wing Reform party is rising in the polls, and the threat Vladimir Putin poses to the world. "Strongmen," May says, cannot be allowed to proliferate at the expense of multilateral institutions.

sample.title: Waymo Leads The 2025 Robotaxi Surge As Zoox Expands And Tesla Races To Catch Up
sample.description:
Alphabet-owned Waymo scaled up and now leads the American robotaxi market by far, while Baidu-owned Apollo Go dominated in China. In the San Francisco Bay Area, there are now multiple robotaxi services operating, including Zoox and Waymo, although only Waymo provides commercial rides completely free of any human safety operators. Tesla finally launched their robotaxis in Austin and San Francisco but both states include human safety supervisors onboard ready to quickly take over driving. In December, Musk confirmed that driverless robotaxi tests had begun in Austin, which drove Tesla stock to a year high.

Chapters:
00:00 - 03:54 U.S. players
04:11 - 06:31 Testing Tesla and Waymo
06:32 - 08:30 Apollo Go and China

sample.title: How to 'invest in' private companies like OpenAI and SpaceX
sample.description:
Private companies like OpenAI and SpaceX have captured enormous investor enthusiasm, driving up their valuations. Yet because they‚Äôre privately held, they‚Äôve remained largely inaccessible to retail investors.

Now a new approached called tokenization could change that by giving retail investors access to investments aligned with the performance of private companies. But some worry that tokenizing private companies could be a way to bypass longstanding regulations meant to protect investors.

sample.title: Why U.S. Shipbuilding Collapsed ‚Äî And The Push To Rebuild It
sample.description:
America used to be a world leader in shipbuilding. But with a shortage of talent, antiquated operating procedures and outdated facilities the industry ‚Äî essential to U.S. energy security and defense ‚Äî is in crisis. China dominates the global commercial shipbuilding industry accounting for 53% of global market share followed by South Korea and Japan. The U.S. accounts for about 0.1%. But that could soon change. In southern Philadelphia, $5 billion is being invested by South Korean shipping conglomerate Hanwha. It hopes to turn this decades old shipyard into a state of the art facility. To look at how shipyards are being revitalized, CNBC traveled to Wisconsin‚Äôs Great Lakes region and to one of America's oldest shipyards in Philadelphia.

Chapters:
0:00 - 2:18 Introduction
2:19 - 5:05 Chapter 1. Hanwha
5:06 - 8:03 Chapter 2. U.S. fleet
8:04 - 11:56 Chapter 3. Worker shortage
11:57 - 16:00 Chapter 4. Automation and robotics

Reporter: Lori Ann LaRocco

sample.title: Inside America‚Äôs Race To Build The Next Generation Of AI Chips
sample.description:
CNBC Marathon investigates the intricate, high-stakes world of semiconductor manufacturing from the Dutch labs powering AI chip breakthroughs to the billion-dollar fabs reshaping U.S. industry.
In a highly secured lab in the Netherlands, ASML spent a decade developing a $400 million machine that‚Äôs transforming how microchips are made. High NA is the latest generation of EUV, the only machines in the world that can etch nanoscopic blueprints on advanced chips for giants like Intel, TSMC and Samsung. The size of a double-decker bus, only five of these machines have been shipped so far. It‚Äôs unclear how Trump‚Äôs tariffs will impact the complex global supply chain for the lithography machines. But without them, no advanced chips can be made by the likes of Nvidia, Apple and AMD. No filming of High NA has ever been allowed until CNBC went to the Netherlands for this exclusive first look.

Texas Instruments is building a $60 billion U.S. manufacturing megaproject where Apple vows to make "critical foundation semiconductors" for iPhones and other devices. CNBC went to Sherman, Texas, for an exclusive first look inside the newest fab of seven TI's building in Utah and Texas to provide U.S.-made chips to customers like Nvidia and Ford. TI shares have suffered amid tariff concerns, and it's lost analog market share for several years, but top leaders are confident about the huge spend.

iPhone Air was the big star unveiled by Apple in early September but inside was another hardware set launched that day: three new custom Apple microchips. Apple‚Äôs A19 Pro SoC prioritizes AI workloads with neural accelerators added to the GPU cores. Replacing Broadcom and Qualcomm parts is the N1 and C1X, Apple‚Äôs first iPhone networking chip and second-generation iPhone modem. CNBC sat down with three Apple executives for the first U.S. interviews about its move to control all core iPhone chips.

This CNBC Marathon looks at the global race to build AI chips and how Apple is using the chips.

Chapters:
00:00 Introduction
01:00: How ASML Makes Chips Faster With Its New $400 Million High NA Machine (Published May 2025)
18:09: Why Texas Instruments Is Betting $60 Billion On Making Cheap Chips In The U.S. (Published August 2025)
33:48: How Apple‚Äôs New iPhone Chips Enable On-Device AI (Published September 2025)

Produced by: Katie Tarasov
Edited by: Evan Lee Miller, Mike Heffron
Additional Camera: Magdalena Petrova, Andrew Evers, Graham Merwin
Animation: Jason Reginato, Mithra Krishnan, Emily Park
Senior Director of Video: Jeniece Pettitt
Additional Editing: Isabel Iino
Additional Footage: TSML, Intel, Getty Images, TSMC, Zeiss, Texas Instruments, KTEN, Samsung, Nvidia, Qualcomm

sample.title: How AI Is Changing Shopping
sample.description:
Consumers' increasing use of AI for shopping ideas and deals is forcing retailers to scramble to stay ahead. Walmart  and Target have partnered with OpenAI to let consumers shop its products through ChatGPT, and Amazon has created its own tools. CNBC's Melissa Repko and Gabrielle Fonrouge break down their reporting on why AI could upend shopping.

sample.title: How much foreign interference is there in UK politics? | BBC Newscast
sample.description:
Today, the government has ordered an independent review into foreign financial interference in UK politics.

The government say this is in response to what it called the ‚Äúshocking‚Äù case of Nathan Gill, the former leader of Reform UK in Wales. Gill was jailed in November, after admitting to taking bribes for pro-Russian interviews and speeches when he was a Member of the European Parliament (MEP).

Announcing the review, Communities Secretary Steve Reed said the government must "learn the lessons" from the case so "this can never happen again". Responding to Reed's statement in the Commons, Reform UK's deputy leader Richard Tice said his party welcomed the review but called on the government to also make sure it looked into the influence of China on the Labour Party. Victoria and Chris discuss what the review could mean

Plus, President Donald Trump has filed, what is being reported as, a $5 billion dollar lawsuit against the BBC. Caitr√≠ona Perry and the FT‚Äôs global media editor Daniel Thomas explain what‚Äôs in the lawsuit and why the BBC has said it plans to fight it.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#BBCNews #UKPolitics #Russia

sample.title: Fat-shaming claims dropped from Lizzo lawsuit. #Lizzo #US #BBCNews
Children with cancer scammed out of millions fundraised for their treatment, BBC finds | BBC News
sample.description:
A fundraising campaign raised $27,000 in the name of seven-year-old Khalil, who had cancer. However, he did not receive the money for his treatment. The family was told that the campaign had failed.

Across the world, desperate parents of sick or dying children are being exploited by online scam campaigns, the BBC World Service has discovered.

BBC have identified 15 families who say they got little to nothing of the funds raised and often had no idea the campaigns had even been published, despite undergoing harrowing filming.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#Children #Health #BBCNews

sample.title: Why is Trump suing the BBC? | Global News Podcast
sample.description:
President Donald Trump has filed a multi-billion dollar lawsuit in Florida, accusing the BBC of defamation and of violating a trade practices law.
 
The BBC apologised to him last month, but rejected his demands for compensation and disagreed there was a "basis for a defamation claim".
 
We speak to our North America correspondent, Nomia Iqbal and UK political correspondent, Rob Watson.
 
Subscribe to the Global News Podcast wherever you get your podcasts or find more episodes here: https://bbc.in/GlobalNewsPodcast
